MURNANE, The Road to Kadesh: A Historical Interpretation of the Battle Relief of King Sety I at Karnak (Michael Green), 184; Winfried BARTA, Die Bedeutung der Jenseitsbücher für den verstorbenen König (J. KEMP, Amarna Reports II (Robert Hari †), 194; Winifred NEEDLER, Predynastic and Archaic Egypt in the Brooklyn Museum (Stan Hendrickx), 197; Gustav Adolf LEHMANN, Die mykenisch-frühgriechische Welt und der östliche Mittelmeerraum in der Zeit der « Seevölker »-Invasionen um 1200 v. Chr. (K.A. Kitchen), 199.

refBibs.title: Achaean question, and the traditions relating to the Trojan War The Trojan War, its historicity and context (First Greenbank Colloquium Bristol, 1982; and on a less technical level, Michael W o o d In Lehmann's use of Egyptian data, there are some errors that should have been avoided. Thus, he continues to cite an imaginary year 4 of Merenptah from the Amada stela (K R I, IV, 1:12, see his p. 54, n. Ill), although this has been corrected to Year 5 over four years ago (see KRI, IV This also applies to Lehmann's p. 29, n. 55. Section 8 rounds off the Greek world following the changes from c. 1200 BC, while Section 9 in turn looks at the Sea Peoples as settled along the coasts of the Levant then. He makes uncritical use of the sometimes rather problematic translation of Wenamun by Goedicke The reviewer's essay on the Philistines and Sea Peoples in D

host.title: Search of the Trojan War Ancient Egyptian Literature, II
this little book is well written, weighs the evidence and data judiciously, and is well documented, and will be a useful work for ready reference
